pullRequest.body:
# Tensor-Hom adjunction
Let $R$ be a commutative ring and $S$ any ring. Let $X$ be an $(S,R)$-bimoule. Then the tensor functor $(X \otimes_R \cdot)$ is a functor from left $R$-modules to left $S$-modules; and the hom-functor $Hom_S(X, \cdot)$ is a functor from left $S$-modules to left $R$-modules. For another left $S$-module $Y$, the left $R$-module structure of $Hom_S(X, Y)$ is given by $s \cdot f := x \mapsto f(s \cdot x)$.  These two functors are adjoint.. In particular we have that
```math
{\rm Hom}_{S}(X\otimes_R Y, Z) \cong {\rm Hom}_R (Y, {\rm Hom}_S (X, Z))
```

## Implementation notes

1. Why not use the `Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/TensorProduct/Tower.lean`

   In our setting `X` is an `(R, S)` bimodule and `Y` an `R`-module and `Z` an `S`-module
   so to use the `Tower` file, we need `S` to be an `R`-algebra which is a luxury we do not have.
   But note that in `Tower` file, `curry` and `uncurry` are both tri-linear maps. So `Tower` file
   allows interplay of 3 rings which is not allowed in this file.

2. We require `R` to be commutative but we never used anything commutative. This is because of tensor product requires commutativity, but thanks to @alreadydone, this assumption could be removed soon. 

I think this PR should wait for Junyan's attempt on removing commutativity, so it is marked as draft and wip for now

---

nodes.body: I am already lost on the description of the PR before I've even looked at the files. You say X is an (R,S)-bimodule. Presumably this means R and S^{op} act on the left on X? So how is `(X ⊗[R] .)` an S-module and how does `X →ₗ[S] .` make sense (because X is not an S-module)?

> I am already lost on the description of the PR before I've even looked at the files. You say X is an (R,S)-bimodule. Presumably this means R and S^{op} act on the left on X? So how is `(X ⊗[R] .)` an S-module and how does `X →ₗ[S] .` make sense (because X is not an S-module)?

I think I meant that `X` is both an `R`-module and an `S`-module such that `R`-action and `S`-action commutes. Let me change the description.

Still trying to get my head around the `LinearMap.lean` changes. The `bimodule` docstring says "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ an S-module, then M ⟶ M₂ is also a bimodule".

`bimodule` shows "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ a left S-module, then M →ₗ[S] M₂ is a right R-module", I think. What is the other module structure on `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? For example I can't see that `M →ₗ[S] M₂` is a left `S`-module, without some assumptions:

```lean
import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.LinearMap

set_option autoImplicit false

variable {R S M M₂ : Type*}
  [Semiring R] [Semiring S] [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid M₂]
  [Module R M] [Module S M]
  [Module S M₂]
  [Module S (M →ₗ[S] M₂)]

-- If we define `(s • f) x = s • f x`, we must have `s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x`
example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = s • f x) :
    s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x :=
  calc s • s' • f x
    _ = s • f (s' • x)   := by rw [map_smul]
    _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
    _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
    _ = s' • s • f x     := by rw [h]

-- If we define `(s • f) x = f (s • x)` we must have `f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x)`
example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = f (s • x)) :
    f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x) :=
  calc f (s • s' • x)
    _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
    _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
    _ = s' • f (s • x)   := by rw [h]
    _ = f (s' • s • x)   := by rw [map_smul _ s']
```

> Still trying to get my head around the `LinearMap.lean` changes. The `bimodule` docstring says "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ an S-module, then M ⟶ M₂ is also a bimodule".
> 
> `bimodule` shows "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ a left S-module, then M →ₗ[S] M₂ is a right R-module", I think. What is the other module structure on `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? For example I can't see that `M →ₗ[S] M₂` is a left `S`-module, without some assumptions:
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.LinearMap
> 
> set_option autoImplicit false
> 
> variable {R S M M₂ : Type*}
>   [Semiring R] [Semiring S] [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid M₂]
>   [Module R M] [Module S M]
>   [Module S M₂]
>   [Module S (M →ₗ[S] M₂)]
> 
> -- If we define `(s • f) x = s • f x`, we must have `s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x`
> example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = s • f x) :
>     s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x :=
>   calc s • s' • f x
>     _ = s • f (s' • x)   := by rw [map_smul]
>     _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
>     _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
>     _ = s' • s • f x     := by rw [h]
> 
> -- If we define `(s • f) x = f (s • x)` we must have `f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x)`
> example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = f (s • x)) :
>     f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x) :=
>   calc f (s • s' • x)
>     _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
>     _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
>     _ = s' • f (s • x)   := by rw [h]
>     _ = f (s' • s • x)   := by rw [map_smul _ s']
> ```

how about these
```lean
open MulOpposite in
/-- If `M` is an `(R, S)` bimodule and `M₂` an `S`-module, then `M ⟶ M₂` is also
  a bimodule-/
protected def bimodule
    [Module R M] [Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M] [SMulCommClass R Sᵐᵒᵖ M] [Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M₂] :
    Module Rᵐᵒᵖ (M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂) where
  smul r l :=
  { toFun := fun x => l (r.unop • x)
    map_add' := fun x y => by dsimp; rw [smul_add, map_add]
    map_smul' := fun s x => by dsimp; rw [smul_comm, map_smul] }
  one_smul l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = _ by rw [unop_one, one_smul]
  mul_smul r₁ r₂ l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = l _ by rw [unop_mul, mul_smul]
  smul_zero r := rfl
  smul_add r l₁ l₂ := LinearMap.ext fun x => show (l₁ + _) _ = _ by
    rw [LinearMap.add_apply, LinearMap.add_apply]; rfl
  add_smul r₁ r₂ l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = l _ + l _ by
    rw [unop_add, add_smul, map_add]
  zero_smul l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = 0 by rw [unop_zero, zero_smul, map_zero]
  ```

If `M` is a `(R, S)`-bimodule (i.e. type theoretically `Module R M` `Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M` and `SMulCommClass R Sᵐᵒᵖ M`) and `M₂` a right `S`-module (type theoreticaly `Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M₂`), then the right `S`-linear map `M ⟶ M₂` (type theoretically `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂`) has a right `R`-module structure?

cc @kbuzzard

> If `M` is a left `(R, S)`-bimodule (i.e. left `R`-mod and right `S`-mod) and `M₂` a right `S`-module, then the right `S`-linear map `M ⟶ M₂` has a right `R`-module structure?
> 
> cc @kbuzzard

Sorry, I don't get it. Typo? ~"left bimodule" and~ "right linear map"?

> > If `M` is a left `(R, S)`-bimodule (i.e. left `R`-mod and right `S`-mod) and `M₂` a right `S`-module, then the right `S`-linear map `M ⟶ M₂` has a right `R`-module structure?
> > cc @kbuzzard
> 
> Sorry, I don't get it. Typos? "left bimodule" and "right linear map"?

Sorry I typed in a hurry, `M` is `(R, S)`-bimodule, "right" `S`-linear map is to stress `M ⟶ M₂` is `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂`
Can we still say something in terms of `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? Like, does `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂` being a right `R`-module make `M →ₗ[S] M₂` a left `R`-module, I wonder

> Can we still say something in terms of `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? Like, does `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂` being a right `R`-module make `M →ₗ[S] M₂` a left `R`-module, I wonder

Since `M` and `M₂` are right-modules, `M →ₗ[S] M₂` does not type check.

> In our setting `X` is an `(R, S)` bimodule and `Y` an `R`-module and `Z` an `S`-module
> so to use the `Tower` file, we need `S` to be an `R`-algebra which is a luxury we do not have.
> But note that in `Tower` file, `curry` and `uncurry` are both tri-linear maps. So `Tower` file
> allows interplay of 3 rings which is not allowed in this file.

Is there no generalization that covers both cases? It's very possible that the `Tower` file is insufficiently general.

I didn't carefully read all the discusions, but I think the following is the simplest formulation: Let $R$ and $S$ be arbitrary (not necessarily commutative) (semi)rings. If $X$ is a $(S,R)$-bimodule, then $X\otimes_R -$ is a functor from (left) $R\text{-Mod}$ to (left) $S\text{-Mod}$ (and [ModuleCat.extendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.extendScalars) is a special case), and $\text{Hom}_S(X,-)$ is a functor from (left) $S\text{-Mod}$ to (left) $R\text{-Mod}$ (this has been pointed on [here on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/left.20vs.20right.20modules.20in.20tensor.20products/near/265579253), and [ModuleCat.coextendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.coextendScalars) is a special case). The adjunction says $\text{Hom}_S(X\otimes_R M, N) \cong \text{Hom}_R(M, \text{Hom}_S(X,N))$ for $M$ in $R\text{-Mod}$ and $N$ in $S\text{-Mod}$.

One obstruction of doing this in full generality is that we currently can't talk about tensor products over a noncommutative (semi)ring in mathlib; I think we'd better generalize it soon, maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it but non-reducibly (which means we can put different instances on the commutative version so as to avoid the diamond from $R$ acting on $M\otimes_R N$ via $N$ due to the presence of [SMulCommClass R R M] from commutativity of R, etc.).

cc @Julian-Kuelshammer @semorrison who are probably knowledgeable/interested.

> maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it

I think we're going to be blocked by #7152 on that front. I don't think we should push ahead with a workaround; if this was non-urgent enough to let these mathlib 3 PR that I spent months resolving conflicts on get killed by the port, I think we can afford to wait for someone else to redo it...

> > maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it
> 
> I think we're going to be blocked by #7152 on that front. I don't think we should push ahead with a workaround; if this was non-urgent enough to let these mathlib 3 PR that I spent months resolving conflicts on get killed by the port, I think we can afford to wait for someone else to redo it...

For me, this PR is to get unstuck on flatness, but all I need is a way to construct group maps from tensor product and that could be done by #8519, so this PR can wait as long as #8519 is okay

> I didn't carefully read all the discusions, but I think the following is the simplest formulation: Let R and S be arbitrary (not necessarily commutative) (semi)rings. If X is a (S,R)-bimodule, then X⊗R− is a functor from (left) R-Mod to (left) S-Mod (and [ModuleCat.extendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.extendScalars) is a special case), and HomS(X,−) is a functor from (left) S-Mod to (left) R-Mod (this has been pointed on [here on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/left.20vs.20right.20modules.20in.20tensor.20products/near/265579253), and [ModuleCat.coextendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.coextendScalars) is a special case). The adjunction says HomS(X⊗RM,N)≅HomR(M,HomS(X,N)) for M in R-Mod and N in S-Mod.
> 
> One obstruction of doing this in full generality is that we currently can't talk about tensor products over a noncommutative (semi)ring in mathlib; I think we'd better generalize it soon, maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it but non-reducibly (which means we can put different instances on the commutative version so as to avoid the diamond from R acting on M⊗RN via N due to the presence of [SMulCommClass R R M] from commutativity of R, etc.).
> 
> cc @Julian-Kuelshammer @semorrison who are probably knowledgeable/interested.

I have changed the implementation to that `X` is an `(S, R)`-bimodule
I have merged your commit @alreadydone, thanks!

Great, okay. Could you please make sure that the doc-strings are clear about this?

I've switched to use X as the first argument, and applied some (but not all) of my suggestions above and below at [this commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/13681c3c011947ff34562e3dbb7f403f9b5e1071)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (x : X) (x' : X') : uncurry' l (x ⊗ₜ x') = l x' x := rfl ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (x : X) (x' : X') : uncurry' l (x ⊗ₜ x') = l x' x := rfl ```

Do we lose some generality by assuming `[SMulCommClass R R M]`?

```lean
example [Semiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] [SMulCommClass R R M] (m : M) (r₁ r₂ : R) :
    (r₁ * r₂) • m = (r₂ * r₁) • m := by
  rw [mul_smul, smul_comm, ← mul_smul]
```

If you don't want to assume `CommRing R`, this may be a case where one needs to bite the bullet and use `MulOpposite` to distinguish the left and right actions. For example (just enough to make it work, but perhaps not the best choice):

```suggestion
open MulOpposite in
/-- If `M` is an `(R, S)` bimodule and `M₂` an `S`-module, then `M ⟶ M₂` is also
  a bimodule-/
protected def bimodule
    [Module R M] [Module S M] [SMulCommClass R S M] [Module S M₂] :
    Module Rᵐᵒᵖ (M →ₗ[S] M₂) where
  smul r l :=
  { toFun := fun x => l (r.unop • x)
    map_add' := fun x y => by dsimp; rw [smul_add, map_add]
    map_smul' := fun s x => by dsimp; rw [smul_comm, map_smul] }
  one_smul l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = _ by rw [unop_one, one_smul]
  mul_smul r₁ r₂ l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = l _ by rw [unop_mul, mul_smul]
  smul_zero r := rfl
  smul_add r l₁ l₂ := LinearMap.ext fun x => show (l₁ + _) _ = _ by
    rw [LinearMap.add_apply, LinearMap.add_apply]; rfl
  add_smul r₁ r₂ l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = l _ + l _ by
    rw [unop_add, add_smul, map_add]
  zero_smul l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = 0 by rw [unop_zero, zero_smul, map_zero]
```

Not assuming either `CommRing R` or `SMulCommClass R R M` here makes things difficult in "TensorHomAdjunction.lean", of course. I won't try to add `ᵐᵒᵖ` there, since it depends on your decision here.
Thanks for the suggestion! Since `R` is assumed to be commutative anyway, changing `TensorHomAdjunction.lean` is just a slight bother to do.

```suggestion
    [Module R M] [Module S M] [SMulCommClass R S M] [Module S M₂]
    (r : Rᵐᵒᵖ) (l : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (m : M) :
    (r • l) m = l (r.unop • m) := rfl
```

```suggestion
Consider two commutative rings `R` and `S` and `X` an `(R, S)`-bimodule.
```

```suggestion
`R`-module. They form an adjunction. In particular we have that

to the category of `S`-modules.

```suggestion
`M × N → C` that is zero-preserving, additive in both arguments and compatible with scalar action.
```
Your assumptions about the definition of "bimodule" in this file are not consistent with e.g. the use of the term in `Algebra.Module.Bimodule`.
In the latest change, I think I have updated this file so that the bimodule is actually mathematically correct.

I think this has just substantially confused the issue; If we're using `Sᵐᵒᵖ` everywhere and `S` nowhere, then we've sacrificed generality and forced ourselves onto a more fragile end of mathlib (c.f. #7152).

If I understand this issue correctly, then we have three options

1. assume `X` is both a (left) `R`-module and a (left) `S`-module such that `R`-action and `S`-action commutes. Then define everything in terms of left modules. This would not technically be the tensor-hom adjunction, but it is easier to work with and to maintain (at least for now, maybe situation would improve after #7152)
2. assume `X` is an `(R, S)`-bimodule and define the tensor-hom adjunction as an adjunction between left `R`-module and right `S`-module. This would force us to use `Module S^{mop} ...` and mixing left module and right module is awkward.
3. assume `R, S` are both commutative and pretend that left and right module makes no difference

currently things are implemented as option 2.
These should not be constrained to the same universe
In commite [63ec5b0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8495/commits/63ec5b0710f344c77c1bf2bb16fb0c60f39cfe85) I have generalized the universe levels
This instance is unfortunately bad, as it forms diamonds. I also don't see ℤ in the statement, so am puzzled by the name.
This instance is to synthesize that when `N` is `AddCommGroup` then `Module ℤᵐᵒᵖ N`, but since it works for any commutative ring, I though I generalize it to `R'` (but I forgot to change name)

I have moved the three akward instance to the same place in `Algebra.Module.Basic` file to review them easier:

```lean
def Module.fromOppositeModule [CommSemiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module Rᵐᵒᵖ M] :
    Module R M :=
  Module.compHom M ((RingHom.id R).toOpposite fun _ _ => mul_comm _ _)

def Module.toOppositeModule [CommSemiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] :
    Module Rᵐᵒᵖ M :=
  Module.compHom M ((RingHom.id R).fromOpposite fun _ _ => mul_comm _ _)

def Module.intMopBimodule [CommSemiring R] [AddCommGroup M] [Module R M] :
    SMulCommClass R ℤᵐᵒᵖ M where
  smul_comm r' z n := show r' • z.unop • n = z.unop • r' • n from smul_comm _ _ _
```

I'm afraid these are all a bad idea, because now you have two instances for `op r₁ • r₂`, the existing one `r₂ * r₁` and the new one `r₁ * r₂`.

If you need `Module Rᵐᵒᵖ M`, then the correct thing to do is add `[Module Rᵐᵒᵖ M]` to your lemma 

If you need `Module ℤᵐᵒᵖ M`, then we need to add `op_zsmul` to `AddCommGroup`, as described in #7152.

In commite [63ec5b0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8495/commits/63ec5b0710f344c77c1bf2bb16fb0c60f39cfe85) I have deleted these 3 instances and inlined them where necessary execept for one private instance
This should be stated with `IsCentralScalar`, and not the instances above.
This definition is no longer needed
I think the approach here is backwards; you should do everything universe-(and perhaps ring-) polymorphically *outside* category theory, then recover the category-theoretic version as a special case.

In commite [63ec5b0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8495/commits/63ec5b0710f344c77c1bf2bb16fb0c60f39cfe85) I have moved `(un)curry` outside and recovered the category-theoretic version as a special case. Can you check if this is what you meant?

This instance is still a pretty bad idea, such that I think at minimum it should be introduced in a more visible and scary way than an `open bimodule` command.

It would probably be better to untangle where this instance is actually needed, then remove it entirely.

I removed this instance and moved it to `TensorHomAdjunction.lean` as a local instance in [12eeac9](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8495/commits/12eeac90d291b69a9b2fffd4f8d2cc1052343910), is this helpful?

Arguably this should be
```suggestion
    Module Rᵈᵐᵃ (X →ₗ[S] Y) where
```
where `ᵈᵐᵃ` is `DomMulAct`. I don't know if `ᵈᵐᵃ` is sufficiently developed for that to work out of the box.

By chaning this instance, it would manefest what you just commented [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8495#discussion_r1398479089), we have left `R`-module, right `S`-module and `Rᵈᵐᵃ` module (which is right `R` module under the hood?)
Yes, because this is really a right-action!
Since we are working with functors between left `R`-modules and right `S`-modules, we eventually need it to be `R`-module.
Indeed, but I think you can use semilinear maps for that
This result is great! I wonder if we could prove it more easily right at the very beginning (before even the module structure on the tensor product), and prove the current `lift` in terms of it?
I'll have a PR with that shortly...
I actually need this construction more than the adjunction!

```suggestion
left `S`-module and the hom functor `(X →ₗ[S] ·)` from the category of left `S`-module to the
```

```suggestion
Consider the tensor functor `(X ⊗[R] ·)` from the category of left `R`-module to the category of
```
also `S` isn't necessarily commutative (and `R` also once we generalize)

I think the docstrings will need some edits now that X is an (S,R)- rather than (R,S)-bimodule. Maybe 1 can be removed, because I don't think tensoring with X on the right will be natural to work with, as it's a functor from right S-Mod to right R-mod and our ModuleCat is of left modules.
It seems that Lean treats an instance as a non-instance def if it's prefixed with `local`, leading to linter errors. (removed in my commit)
We should be using `X ⊗[R] X'` here. (done in my commit)

Using X as the first factor has the added bonus that only a little help is necessary for Lean to infer the module structure: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/877c9b6d66dd931145c7ecbb11142cc36772304f
and eventually `X ⊗[R] Y` here. (done in my commit)

`{X' : Type v'} [AddCommGroup X'] [Module R X']` can be extracted as `variable` to reuse in the following lemmas (done in my commit). (Or maybe inline all these into `tensorMod`, unless you want to give weaker instances `MulAction` `DistribMulAction` under correspondingly weaker assumptions.)

Also, why use `X'` rather than `Y`? You could call the `R`-module `Y` and call the `S`-module `Z` (change [Module S Y] below to [Module S Z] below). (done in my commit)

```suggestion
Given an `(S, R)`-bimodule `X` and a left `S`-module `Y`, the set of
`S`-linear maps from `X` to `Y` has a left `R`-module structure given by:
-```
l : X →ₗ[S] Y
r : R
x : X
-------------
(r • l) x = l (op r • x)
```

```suggestion
Let `R` be a commutative ring and `S` a ring.
Given an `(S, R)`-bimodule `X`, a left `R`-module `Y` and a left `S`-module `Z`,
any `S`-linear map `X ⊗[R] Y ⟶ Z` can by curried into a bilinear map `Y ⟶ X ⟶ Z` that
is `R`-linear in the first argument and `S`-linear in the second.
```
(applied in my commit)
maybe we can preemptively remove the "commutative" too, even though we haven't generalized tensor products yet ...

```suggestion
Let `X` be an `(S,R)`-bimodule. Then `(X ⊗[R] ·)` is a functor from the category of
left `R`-modules to the category of `S`-modules.
```
(applied in my commit)

```suggestion
Let `X` be an `(S,R)`-bimodule. Then `(X →ₗ[S] ·)` is a functor from the category of
left `S`-modules to the category of left `R`-modules.
```
(applied in my commit)

Indentations are off.
(fixed in my commit)
Doesn't `inferInstance` find this one?

It's [missing `SMulCommClass R S A`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/877c9b6d66dd931145c7ecbb11142cc36772304f#diff-a87116f7f640e8e18c30fa6377b63941056a8eb5d809154d94fea7115d876f3fR54-R57). @jjaassoonn maybe you want to merge this commit as well.

This instance from `[CommRing R] [Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X]` to `Module R X` isn't safe as it forms a diamond with [Semiring.toOppositeModule](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Basic.html#Semiring.toOppositeModule).
Lean 4 seems to have trouble with `local instance` so maybe we need to use `local attribute [instance]`.
Of course, when we generalize tensor products it would take `Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X` directly .

I think it may be nice to ensure that any `Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X` instance we register for a CommRing R is always "defeq" to the `Module R X` instance; e.g. `Module Rᵐᵒᵖ R` would also be left multiplication rather than right multiplication, which (I think) could be achieved with a higher priority instance for CommRings that override the general Semiring.toOppositeModule. We could even have an instance from `[CommRing R] [Module R X]` to `Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X`. This would also render issue #7152 void, I think.

Instance priority is never suitable as a means of ensuring coherent instance resolution; any lemmas about the "wrong" low-priority instance can introduce it back into the goal.

I don't understand the motivation for this instance anyway; if you really think you need it, you should instead be writing `[Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X] [Module R X] [IsCentralScalar R X]`.

> Instance priority is never suitable as a means of ensuring coherent instance resolution; any lemmas about the "wrong" low-priority instance can introduce it back into the goal.

Okay!

> I don't understand the motivation for this instance anyway; if you really think you need it, you should instead be writing `[Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X] [Module R X] [IsCentralScalar R X]`.

The idea is that `[Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X]` is the morally correct assumption, but mathlib's TensorProduct uses an `R`-action rather than `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-action on the first factor, so we currently need `leftMod_eq_rightMod` for some existing instances to apply. Once we refactor TensorProduct` and switch to using `Rᵐᵒᵖ`-action in the existing instances, `leftMod_eq_rightMod` will no longer be needed. I think adding a local instance is better than adding assumptions, as it doesn't change the interface.

I think we should write the interface for the thing we actually have, not add hacks that make it seem like we have the one that we wish we had. It's not mathematically an extra assumption anyway, since we have `CommRing R`.

If we want to fit the current interface, we would use `[Module R X]` as the sole assumption and derive `Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X` from it and we'd just be reversing the direction of this instance rather than removing it. Alternatively, the current mathlib practice would be doing this `mop` conversion under the hood (since we always have a CommSemiring when talking about tensor products), but if we do it here we'd just make our future refactoring job harder, I think.

I might start experimenting with refactoring TensorProduct tonight and open a draft PR. @jjaassoonn's #8536 seems to be working towards that but doesn't change the definition of TensorProduct yet; maybe he has some further progress?
Forgot to say: if you use `[Module Rᵐᵒᵖ X] [Module R X] [IsCentralScalar R X]`, every caller of `TensorProduct.hcurry` would have to supply those assumptions, probably as local or inlined instances.

(Edit: this doesn't work because it's not good for `hom_bimodule`)
~~Maybe switch these to~~
```suggestion
variable [AddCommGroup X] [Module R X] [Module S X] [SMulCommClass R S X]

open MulOpposite
```
~~for now and switch back after we generalize TensorProduct?~~

This instance could be moved to the appropriate file (where LinearMap is defined), if not promoted to a global instance. 

On the other hand, `Module.tensorLeftOfMop` will be replaced by the correct version of `TensorProduct.leftModule`, and `Module.ofMop` will be gone after TensorProduct refactoring, so let's keep them here.
This instance should be using `DomMulAct`, because it is acting on the domain of the linear map. With that change, it is *reasonably* safe as a global instance.

Added some DomMulAct instances [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/0f9dd8841bc34771150aaf8eec70a7274c98aee7)
Refactoring the tensor product file is roughly 1/3 complete; the new `lift` will be the `huncurry` here.

```suggestion
noncomputable def TensorProduct.hcurry (l : X ⊗[R] Y →ₗ[S] Z) : Y →ₗ[R] X →ₗ[S] Z where
```
In my opinion this is a rather weird meaning of "bilinear", and so could probably do with more comments.

Indeed when I modify the docstring I didn't realize it doesn't make perfect sense to say it's `R`-linear in the first argument, as `Z` has no `R`-module structure, even though `X ->[S] Z` as a whole has.

No, this is definitely not more natural, and in fact doesn't generalize as well!

The right way to think about order when `Hom` is involved is as $\mathsf{Hom}(X, Y) \cong X^* \otimes Y$. Thus the "natural" thing to say is:

$$\mathsf{Hom}(X \otimes Y \to Z) \cong (X \otimes Y)^* \otimes Z \cong Y^* \otimes X^* \otimes Y \cong \mathsf{Hom}(Y \to \mathsf{Hom}(X \to Z)).$$

This is the thing that keeps working in the most noncommutative settings.
This makes sense! Thanks

pullRequest.title: feat : Tensor-Hom adjunction in the category of modules

nodes.body: I am already lost on the description of the PR before I've even looked at the files. You say X is an (R,S)-bimodule. Presumably this means R and S^{op} act on the left on X? So how is `(X ⊗[R] .)` an S-module and how does `X →ₗ[S] .` make sense (because X is not an S-module)?

> I am already lost on the description of the PR before I've even looked at the files. You say X is an (R,S)-bimodule. Presumably this means R and S^{op} act on the left on X? So how is `(X ⊗[R] .)` an S-module and how does `X →ₗ[S] .` make sense (because X is not an S-module)?

I think I meant that `X` is both an `R`-module and an `S`-module such that `R`-action and `S`-action commutes. Let me change the description.

Still trying to get my head around the `LinearMap.lean` changes. The `bimodule` docstring says "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ an S-module, then M ⟶ M₂ is also a bimodule".

`bimodule` shows "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ a left S-module, then M →ₗ[S] M₂ is a right R-module", I think. What is the other module structure on `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? For example I can't see that `M →ₗ[S] M₂` is a left `S`-module, without some assumptions:

```lean
import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.LinearMap

set_option autoImplicit false

variable {R S M M₂ : Type*}
  [Semiring R] [Semiring S] [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid M₂]
  [Module R M] [Module S M]
  [Module S M₂]
  [Module S (M →ₗ[S] M₂)]

-- If we define `(s • f) x = s • f x`, we must have `s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x`
example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = s • f x) :
    s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x :=
  calc s • s' • f x
    _ = s • f (s' • x)   := by rw [map_smul]
    _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
    _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
    _ = s' • s • f x     := by rw [h]

-- If we define `(s • f) x = f (s • x)` we must have `f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x)`
example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = f (s • x)) :
    f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x) :=
  calc f (s • s' • x)
    _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
    _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
    _ = s' • f (s • x)   := by rw [h]
    _ = f (s' • s • x)   := by rw [map_smul _ s']
```

> Still trying to get my head around the `LinearMap.lean` changes. The `bimodule` docstring says "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ an S-module, then M ⟶ M₂ is also a bimodule".
> 
> `bimodule` shows "If M is an (R, S) bimodule and M₂ a left S-module, then M →ₗ[S] M₂ is a right R-module", I think. What is the other module structure on `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? For example I can't see that `M →ₗ[S] M₂` is a left `S`-module, without some assumptions:
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.LinearMap
> 
> set_option autoImplicit false
> 
> variable {R S M M₂ : Type*}
>   [Semiring R] [Semiring S] [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid M₂]
>   [Module R M] [Module S M]
>   [Module S M₂]
>   [Module S (M →ₗ[S] M₂)]
> 
> -- If we define `(s • f) x = s • f x`, we must have `s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x`
> example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = s • f x) :
>     s • s' • f x = s' • s • f x :=
>   calc s • s' • f x
>     _ = s • f (s' • x)   := by rw [map_smul]
>     _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
>     _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
>     _ = s' • s • f x     := by rw [h]
> 
> -- If we define `(s • f) x = f (s • x)` we must have `f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x)`
> example (f : M →ₗ[S] M₂) (s s' : S) (x : M) (h : ∀ x, (s • f) x = f (s • x)) :
>     f (s • s' • x) = f (s' • s • x) :=
>   calc f (s • s' • x)
>     _ = (s • f) (s' • x) := by rw [h]
>     _ = s' • (s • f) x   := by rw [map_smul]
>     _ = s' • f (s • x)   := by rw [h]
>     _ = f (s' • s • x)   := by rw [map_smul _ s']
> ```

how about these
```lean
open MulOpposite in
/-- If `M` is an `(R, S)` bimodule and `M₂` an `S`-module, then `M ⟶ M₂` is also
  a bimodule-/
protected def bimodule
    [Module R M] [Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M] [SMulCommClass R Sᵐᵒᵖ M] [Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M₂] :
    Module Rᵐᵒᵖ (M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂) where
  smul r l :=
  { toFun := fun x => l (r.unop • x)
    map_add' := fun x y => by dsimp; rw [smul_add, map_add]
    map_smul' := fun s x => by dsimp; rw [smul_comm, map_smul] }
  one_smul l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = _ by rw [unop_one, one_smul]
  mul_smul r₁ r₂ l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = l _ by rw [unop_mul, mul_smul]
  smul_zero r := rfl
  smul_add r l₁ l₂ := LinearMap.ext fun x => show (l₁ + _) _ = _ by
    rw [LinearMap.add_apply, LinearMap.add_apply]; rfl
  add_smul r₁ r₂ l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = l _ + l _ by
    rw [unop_add, add_smul, map_add]
  zero_smul l := LinearMap.ext fun x => show l _ = 0 by rw [unop_zero, zero_smul, map_zero]
  ```

If `M` is a `(R, S)`-bimodule (i.e. type theoretically `Module R M` `Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M` and `SMulCommClass R Sᵐᵒᵖ M`) and `M₂` a right `S`-module (type theoreticaly `Module Sᵐᵒᵖ M₂`), then the right `S`-linear map `M ⟶ M₂` (type theoretically `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂`) has a right `R`-module structure?

cc @kbuzzard

> If `M` is a left `(R, S)`-bimodule (i.e. left `R`-mod and right `S`-mod) and `M₂` a right `S`-module, then the right `S`-linear map `M ⟶ M₂` has a right `R`-module structure?
> 
> cc @kbuzzard

Sorry, I don't get it. Typo? ~"left bimodule" and~ "right linear map"?

> > If `M` is a left `(R, S)`-bimodule (i.e. left `R`-mod and right `S`-mod) and `M₂` a right `S`-module, then the right `S`-linear map `M ⟶ M₂` has a right `R`-module structure?
> > cc @kbuzzard
> 
> Sorry, I don't get it. Typos? "left bimodule" and "right linear map"?

Sorry I typed in a hurry, `M` is `(R, S)`-bimodule, "right" `S`-linear map is to stress `M ⟶ M₂` is `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂`
Can we still say something in terms of `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? Like, does `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂` being a right `R`-module make `M →ₗ[S] M₂` a left `R`-module, I wonder

> Can we still say something in terms of `M →ₗ[S] M₂`? Like, does `M →ₗ[Sᵐᵒᵖ] M₂` being a right `R`-module make `M →ₗ[S] M₂` a left `R`-module, I wonder

Since `M` and `M₂` are right-modules, `M →ₗ[S] M₂` does not type check.

> In our setting `X` is an `(R, S)` bimodule and `Y` an `R`-module and `Z` an `S`-module
> so to use the `Tower` file, we need `S` to be an `R`-algebra which is a luxury we do not have.
> But note that in `Tower` file, `curry` and `uncurry` are both tri-linear maps. So `Tower` file
> allows interplay of 3 rings which is not allowed in this file.

Is there no generalization that covers both cases? It's very possible that the `Tower` file is insufficiently general.

I didn't carefully read all the discusions, but I think the following is the simplest formulation: Let $R$ and $S$ be arbitrary (not necessarily commutative) (semi)rings. If $X$ is a $(S,R)$-bimodule, then $X\otimes_R -$ is a functor from (left) $R\text{-Mod}$ to (left) $S\text{-Mod}$ (and [ModuleCat.extendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.extendScalars) is a special case), and $\text{Hom}_S(X,-)$ is a functor from (left) $S\text{-Mod}$ to (left) $R\text{-Mod}$ (this has been pointed on [here on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/left.20vs.20right.20modules.20in.20tensor.20products/near/265579253), and [ModuleCat.coextendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.coextendScalars) is a special case). The adjunction says $\text{Hom}_S(X\otimes_R M, N) \cong \text{Hom}_R(M, \text{Hom}_S(X,N))$ for $M$ in $R\text{-Mod}$ and $N$ in $S\text{-Mod}$.

One obstruction of doing this in full generality is that we currently can't talk about tensor products over a noncommutative (semi)ring in mathlib; I think we'd better generalize it soon, maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it but non-reducibly (which means we can put different instances on the commutative version so as to avoid the diamond from $R$ acting on $M\otimes_R N$ via $N$ due to the presence of [SMulCommClass R R M] from commutativity of R, etc.).

cc @Julian-Kuelshammer @semorrison who are probably knowledgeable/interested.

> maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it

I think we're going to be blocked by #7152 on that front. I don't think we should push ahead with a workaround; if this was non-urgent enough to let these mathlib 3 PR that I spent months resolving conflicts on get killed by the port, I think we can afford to wait for someone else to redo it...

> > maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it
> 
> I think we're going to be blocked by #7152 on that front. I don't think we should push ahead with a workaround; if this was non-urgent enough to let these mathlib 3 PR that I spent months resolving conflicts on get killed by the port, I think we can afford to wait for someone else to redo it...

For me, this PR is to get unstuck on flatness, but all I need is a way to construct group maps from tensor product and that could be done by #8519, so this PR can wait as long as #8519 is okay

> I didn't carefully read all the discusions, but I think the following is the simplest formulation: Let R and S be arbitrary (not necessarily commutative) (semi)rings. If X is a (S,R)-bimodule, then X⊗R− is a functor from (left) R-Mod to (left) S-Mod (and [ModuleCat.extendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.extendScalars) is a special case), and HomS(X,−) is a functor from (left) S-Mod to (left) R-Mod (this has been pointed on [here on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/left.20vs.20right.20modules.20in.20tensor.20products/near/265579253), and [ModuleCat.coextendScalars](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/ModuleCat/ChangeOfRings.html#ModuleCat.coextendScalars) is a special case). The adjunction says HomS(X⊗RM,N)≅HomR(M,HomS(X,N)) for M in R-Mod and N in S-Mod.
> 
> One obstruction of doing this in full generality is that we currently can't talk about tensor products over a noncommutative (semi)ring in mathlib; I think we'd better generalize it soon, maybe by starting a new file, defining the noncommutative tensor product there, and redefining the existing commutative tensor product in terms of it but non-reducibly (which means we can put different instances on the commutative version so as to avoid the diamond from R acting on M⊗RN via N due to the presence of [SMulCommClass R R M] from commutativity of R, etc.).
> 
> cc @Julian-Kuelshammer @semorrison who are probably knowledgeable/interested.

I have changed the implementation to that `X` is an `(S, R)`-bimodule

I've switched to use X as the first argument, and applied some (but not all) of my suggestions above and below at [this commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/13681c3c011947ff34562e3dbb7f403f9b5e1071)
I have merged your commit @alreadydone, thanks!

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat : rework enough-injectiveness proof of groups using character module

nodes.body: The first sentence of the PR description is garbled.

> The first sentence of the PR description is garbled.

the description has been refined, hopefully it is better now.

> > The first sentence of the PR description is garbled.
> 
> the description has been refined, hopefully it is better now.

You say $R$ must be commutative in the PR description. That's not required for anything you say there, however. How much is it actually needed in this PR?

> > > The first sentence of the PR description is garbled.
> > 
> > 
> > the description has been refined, hopefully it is better now.
> 
> You say R must be commutative in the PR description. That's not required for anything you say there, however. How much is it actually needed in this PR?

This PR includes commutative assumption because currently tensor product requires commutative assumption, after #8638 this assumption could be removed

> > > > The first sentence of the PR description is garbled.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > the description has been refined, hopefully it is better now.
> > 
> > 
> > You say R must be commutative in the PR description. That's not required for anything you say there, however. How much is it actually needed in this PR?
> 
> This PR includes commutative assumption because currently tensor product requires commutative assumption, after #8638 this assumption could be removed

Great, okay. Could you please make sure that the doc-strings are clear about this?
